Bottle. Dark, clear Cola brown with lovely thick tan head. Chocolate and light roast. A little thin. I prefer dark Kruso.
Caramel, chocolate on the nose, very light palate, not great deal of flavour happening

Ar: roasted malts, coffee, bread, chocolate, yeast, bread.
Ap: dark Brown colour, beige head.
F: chocolate, bread made with syrup, los bitterness, slightly smokey.
M: average
T: Well made, bit anonymous but a pleasant experience.
Can. Pours brown with a high head. Aroma sweet malts and brown sugar. Very typical, if not the standard of sweet Czech darks.

Pours a small light tan head. Dark in color. I get aromas of honey and faint caramel. It’s smooth to drink, and the honey tones is not overwhelming at all. It’s one of the best lagers I’ve had til’ now.

Bottle. Dark cola colour with a medium thin creamy head. Sweet aroma of caramel and toffee. Taste is roasted malt. Watery texture with lively carbonation. One of my long time favourites of this style.
Brown color with an fine off-white head. Aroma is malty. Sweet and slightly thin roasted flavor.

0.5 bottle. Pleasant aroma of dark roasted malts, a lot of coffee and some nuts as well. Pours a black liquid with scarlet tone, clear topped with a big creamy head. Sweet taste, rather soft although not to a fault. Medium body and what came as a surprise smooth, watery texture which impairs the typical warm sensation of a dark beer. Carbonation between average and soft inclining towards the latter. Definitely short finish. All in all it is a nice beer but nothing outstanding for its own kind, pretty shame it is spoiled with an excess of water.

Can. Pours an auburnish, dark cola with a large, off-white, quickly dissipating head. Aroma is grassy, soapy, metallic, malty. Taste begins as bready malts, quite sweet, some caramel. Finish is malty and herbal as is the aftertaste. Palate is light, quite carbonated, a bit watery. The taste is pretty good, just too sweet. The mixture of malt and herbal hops is great. Just gotta wonder why the need for the sugar? Would be a lot better without it.
Love it, great taste of Prague... Very delicate, with a taste of caramel, should be served in heavy glass stain (as in Prague).
chocolate, brown, clear, brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, flat, astringent,

500ml bottle. Very nice beige foam with small bubbling (almost creamy). The colour is dark brown. Body is medium, and taste is roasted coffee with minimal earth (by Saazer hop?) and very sweet malt behinde these. I liked it, my wife very liked.

500 ml bottle. Poured a dark brown, almost black with a fluffy tan head. For me, this was a bit like Guinness-lite - similar flavours but less intense; similar mouthfeel but not quite as creamy. It is however very smooth and suprisingly light. A very decent beer.
Draft, unfiltered and not pasteurized. Nut brown creamy body and a white creamy head.  Aroma of nuts, caramel and brown sugar. Medium sweet and slightly bitter. Medium body, creamy, soft carbonation.
On tap. Very dark brown with a couple fingers of foamy tan head. Nice mix of roasted malt, caramel and bittersweet chocolate.
Dark brown appearance. Aroma and taste are sweet, malty but not good. Some infections detected.

Bottle @ Home. Pours dark brown with a small creamy tan head. Aroma of malt, nuts, caramel, chocolate notes. Taste is raosted malt, chocolate, caramel, some grassy hop bitterness. Thin to medium body, soft carbonation, dry finish. 200911
A reasonable dark lager style beer. Nothing that interesting about it, has some good malt flavours but is a little thin on the palate. Good bitterness, lighter side of the Dunkel style for me.

Bottle 500ml @ home

Pours dark reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt and caramel. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Bottle:
Medium airy (light) beige head on top of a ruby colored beer.
Smell honey, sweets, molasses, sticky malts (lightly toasted), and a hint of oatmeal.
Taste is a mix of some light sweets like molasses & toasted sticky malts with a medium bitterness, some dark fruits and some herbs.
Taste is much like the smell
Light bitter and lightly sweet from dark fruits (raisin and prunes) aftertaste.
Low carbo, low to medium body, soft light creamy mouthfeel and a light creamy texture.
Bottle. Dark brown/orange with small tan head. Flavour is malt, sweet, caramel, fruit, chocolate, hops and a little bitter.
(Bottle 01/09-2011) Low beige head, clear brown/red color, sweet aroma,  caramel taste, fit body.

Bottle, 50 cl: Clear dark brown beer with a frothy, long lasting, light brown head. Aroma is sweet and bready malty with notes of caramel and brown sugar. Flavor is sweet with very soft non-distinct hops. Soft mouthfeel, moderate body and watery texture. Easy drinkable but too lightly hopped to be interesting.
On tap in Velka Upa. The most common black beer in CZ. Not bad but nothing special either. Sweet tones, mild palate, nice color.

Can and bottle. Clear but decently dark golden-brown. Has sweet bready malts throughout and a thin but quaffable palate. Veers towards sweetness and could cloy in quantity but is overall quite drinkable.

not bad. pours dark clear brown, with tan head. aroma of nuts, coffee and caramel. some sweetness, and balanced with bitterness. not much mouthfeel -  a little thin if anything. still could be a session beer, due to its %.
I guess I’m not a dunkel guy, but drinking this out of a can while stumbling across prague was a less than enjoyable experience. Unpleasantly sweet, with some burnt brown sugar and cheap maple syrup.
Bottle in Moscow I believe. Dark and malty. Kind of sweet. Not bad overall.
Pours a brown colour with an off white head. Malty aroma with caramel and cereal. Watery low carbonated palate. Decent malty flavour with some smoke and a slightly bitter finish.
Cola coloured, very clear. Brown head. Mild aroma, caramel and some apple, also sugar. Very sweet. Ends up being watery quite quickly.
Clear brown amber with a off-white head. Malty bready aroma with some light flowery hops. Low bitterness.

Bottle 50 cl, Koskikapakki, Rovaniemi. Pours clear dark brown with a good tanned head leaving some lacing. Acidy, slight smokey, fruity and roasted. Low carbonation. Finishes watery, bitter malty and roasted.
Can from Alepa Otaniemi. Originally rated on 7.8.2010. Decent dark lager with a slightly metallic taste.

Bottle 0,5 l, is’t pours dark and a little brown with off white medium head.... aroma ...sweet roasted malt, caramel... the flavor is roasted coffee, caramel, sweet, fresh..... it have an sweet palate....nice dunkel beer! :)

Dark amber with light brown head - aroma of sweet malt, some caramel - taste has a nice tone of roasted malt that adds hints of bitterness from roast - finish is a little bit on the thin, but it is still tasty and drinkable
500ml Bottle. Cool label. For czech dunkels it is a bit sweeter imo, despite the low abv. The roasty notes are there.
Black pour, small white head. Aroma has a bit of chocolate and dark fruit but subtle. Flavor is much like a creamy but watery doppelbock. OK.
Bottle 500cl. Dark Coloured brew with dark foam. Malty, not very hoppy, a little bit watery but ok for this ABV.

Appearance: Dark brownish red, clear. Some tan head.
Aroma: Dark malt, roasted. Sweet fruit.
Taste: Slightly roasted, some sweetness. Malt. Shortlived pleasure.
Info: 500ml bottle, 6/6-2011
Dark brown with medium head. Caramel and roasted malt aromas. Watery texture, sweet taste with sweet finish. Medium body,medium carbonation

Pours dark brown with a large, light tan head.
Aroma comprised of caramel, chocolate and nutty malt. Very sweet smelling.
Similar flavours with caramel, nuts and lots of bready malt. Very low bitterness. Quite sweet.
Body is a bit watery, carbonation is too high.
Super easy to drink though.
Bottle. Dark copper, thin tanned head. Aroma is grainy with some cerial and malts, also hay. Taste has caramel, is medium malty, quite much sweetness. Finish is not very hoppy but has ok bitterness

Bottle 500ml. Brown/red color with thick tan head. Average carbonation. Aroma of roasted malts, sweet caramel. A bit watery though. Nothing special, but still quite drinkable. However, not one of the best Czech Dunkels.
This is a good dunkel beer. Lots of caramel (in the end maybe to much?). Nice rocky head. Luckily I bought one can back home (from Moldova). I will save it til I´m alone...
Decent beer with a nice roasty malt taste but let down by a thin palate and watery finish. Disappointing.
Bottled many times, on tap once (so far:P) I guess the bottled ones were generally much better than the tapped one I had today but anyway - drinkable but average beer. way to wattery.

Fine head. Semi lasting. Brown
Light caramel with a hint of chocko
Medium body, medium length
Taste is light caramel

Leicht malziger Antrunk, schnell künstlich süß werdend. Pennetrant, künstlich, etwas herb. Etwas chemisch, schlecht trinkbar. Nix für mich... 	 
Test vom 21.9.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 12,6,7,6,9,6

The colour is rather nice: dark reddish brown, but the tiny, fizzy, tan head lives for about 10 seconds and leaves the beer looking rather lifeless. The beer smells very close to the jar of malt extract that I keep in my refrigerator! In addition I get caramel and molasses. The taste is what you would expect from the sweet malty aroma: light sweet both initially and in the finish. The flavours are exciting: in addition to the obvious sweet malts, there are also raisins and blackcurrant. Average to soft carbonation. The Kozel is a good brew, but it’s maybe a bit 1 dimensional: the aroma, taste and flavours are totally dominated by the malty sweetness, and there is no evolution: the initial impression is what you end up with in the finish as well.
[50 cl bottle, ICA, Hasle, Oslo]

the liquid is of a dark brown colour and pours a thin silky head that keeps it’s form for a relatively long time. looks like a nice intact dark lager. aromas of rye and even chocolate are present. a very enjoyable sweet taste and aftertaste make it a surprisingly whole experience. there isn’t too much to this beer to talk about, but what there is, it is very nicely done. there is very little variety in taste and aroma, but the full experience is so intact that it delivers what it says it will; a very honest beer. what i like about this beer is that it is so easy to drink and responds well to the temperature you drink it at. works very well even when it’s very cooled down. this is definitely one of my favourite standard dark czech lagers with it’s strong inner balance and identity.
Bottle 500ml. Pours clear dark brown with thick, diminising tan head. Aroma is caramel, roasted maltiness. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter. Medium body, thin to oily, soft carbonation.
Clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet malty and caramel. Flavor is quite sweet. Sweet finish. Watery. There’s not much to this beer except malty sweetness. 130910
Excellent beer, dark as night, but with a slight lightness in flavour that makes it so easy to drink

Nagyon sötétbarna színe van, egy halványan csillogó bíbor árnyalattal, habja sárgás-világosbarnás és kissé krémes, könnyed. Íze pörkölt malátás, továbbá rendkívül erősen tejkaramellás és vaníliás. Ez a tejkaramellás-vaníliás páros az ízét is meghatározza, van benne valami tejeskávés, cukros, reggeli italos, ugyanakkor gyümölcsös is,  utóízében pedig már a kávé is megjelenik. Száraz, nem túl édes dunkel, ami baromi jól csúszik, de nagy bajom vele, hogy túlságosan vizes, mert ilyen ízek mellé egy kicsit haraphatóbb testre vágynék, különben nagyon is rendben lenne, sőt!

0.5l bottle. Pours a really dark ruby body with a tiny dark beige head leaving big lacings. Aromas are some what sweet with thin roasted malts, hints of flower water and some caramel. The first few times I’ve tasted this I’ve had it refrigerator-cold. Then I think the body gets to thin and watery. In room temperature the body was surprisingly decent, at least for a 3.8 percenter, only a bit watery in the ending. Tastes lightly roasted malts and a mild dry sweetness with a medium dry finish. Not to exciting in any way, but quite refreshing and easy to drink.

Quick-review:
Roasted malts, bitter chocolate. Some spices and vanilla aswell.. Good mouthfeel, but drops in the middle. Refreshing, easy to drink. Alcohol is not king, well-crafted beer is!

Canned, 50 cl. Pours dark but clear and red beer. Forms a nice beige head.  Aroma: Malt, small feeling of smoke and soil. Taste: Lightly sweet and bitter. Little metallic. Palate: Light bodied beer with sticky and thin texture. Average carbonation. Dry finish.
Flaske 50 cl. Brun  farve med rødelig skær, beige hoved som hurtigt falder. Aroma er brændt malt og sødme. Smagen er ristet og karamel met sødlige toner. Lidt tynd og vandig med lille bitter finale.

0,5 l can from the supermarket. A cheap beer brought for chinese take-away. Thumps up for the low abv. (3,8 %) Red-brown colour. Malty aroma with notes of caramel and hops. The flavour is dominated by malt with some sweetness. Maybe a bit watery, but very good value for money.

nothing standout, ok for a cheap dark beer... tastes sweet with maybe a bit of tomato sauce with a mild coffee note, nice dark colour to it, head doesnt last long though, i enjoyed this beer much more the last time that i had it,

Cheap and tasty beer. A bit too sweet, in the other hand the taste is really warm and rich.
(New rating, not so tasty or rich after all!)

50cl bottle from an Albert supermarket, Prague, only 50c.
Nice dark beer, plenty of flavour despite it being only 3.8%
Brown colour with plenty of light brown head. Aroma of caramel malts and grains. Flavour is sweet. Roasted malts and grains with a little bit of caramel. Tasty beer with an acceptable price tag.

500 ml bottle in Germany. Is a dark non see through chestnut color. Has a very full light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt carmel that tingels the nose. Taste has hints of smoke with strong nugget, and earth. Palate is very smooth and you almost miss it if your catch is not fast enough. A pleasure to drink. Very nice!

Barna színű sör, amin átnézve egy rubinvörös ragyogást lehet tapasztalni. A tetején lévő hab közepes méretű, világosbarna, buborékokkal teli és gyorsan, de nem nyom nélkül tűnik el. Édeskés, karamellás illata van, amiben érezni egy kis aszalt szilvát és fűszereket. Íze is édeskésen, medvecukrosan kezdődik, aztán csatlakozik egy jó adag maláta, pörkölt magvak, fekete csokoládé és kávé. Kissé vizes de nincs túl vékony teste és közepesen szénsavas. Utóíze kávézaccos, pirítós kenyeres, száraz és kitölti a szájat. Kellemes cseh barna, talán lehetne egy kicsit testesebbre és erősebbre főzni. Finom.
Black colored brew. Roasted malts, chocolate in the aroma. Chocolate flavor, some fruity notes and a nice ending of dark chocolate and some caramel. Nice dunkel.

On tap at the "Yanshuf" bar in Haifa, Israel, keg, pours dark brown reddish with a nice head that dissipates slowly, with nice lacing, sweetish, chocolate, slightly toast and slightly fruity aroma, chocolate aftertaste, coffee hints, and overall a very good dunkel beer.

Bottle @ Home

A fine and enjoyable beer - it enjoys the benefits of being rich and interesting and still easily drinkable. This beer looks beautiful; a dark pour with a huge tan head. The aroma and flavour it dominated by rich roasted malt and chocolate notes with a slight sweetness to it. Mouthfeel is too thin unfortunately which detracts from the overall enjoyment. Nonetheless an enjoyable and rewarding brew.
Red brown beer.Smell dry plum and Tiramisu.Taste medium sweet,dry plum,light coffee and caramel.notes of metallic.Good drinkability.
Has this on tap some where in Prague. I remember liking it quite a bit. The missus too.  Richer than I expected. Serving: Tap

500 ml can. Rated @ 10.4.2009.

Pours a brown colour with a light brown head. Aroma of roasted malts with caramel notes. Flavour of caramel malts with some roastiness and metallic notes. Medium bodied with a watery mouthfeel. Decent.
Moderate hoppy and chocolate aroma. Huge, frothy, off-white head. Excellent lacing. Mostly lasting longevity. Clear, amber body. Moderate sweet flavor. Medium palate.

Bottle from Alko in Pello.

Dark brown with a nice tan head. 

Bread, roasted malt and caramel in the aroma. Quite thin mouth feel, taste of chocolate, nuts, roasted malt and caramel. An ok beer.
Bottle. Amber dark color body, nice kinda brown head. Malty caramel taste. It’s a good dark lager this one

On tap at Mosquto pub, Split. It poured dark red to brown body with small brown head. Fine coffee aroma, along with sweet caramel and burnt sugar. Slightly sour flavor, mostly consisting of coffee, but very watery. Some sweetish burnt sugar present. to balance it a little bit. As of such thin body I couldn’t expect nice long finish such as this beer has. Ends sweetly with caramel and even some fruitiness. I know it’s only 3,8% ABV but it lacks so much body to be more interesting!
Bottle. Average size tan foamy head over a clear dark garnet body. Aroma/taste of molasses, dark sugar, toast and dark chocolate. A bit watery, thin light bodied.
Bevuta in bottiglia da 0,50 a Plzen, è una birra abbastanza comune in Cechia. Di aspetto molto bello, il gusto tradisce un pò le aspettative.

Bottle from "KülönlegesSörökBoltja", Bp.
Dark brown coloured czeh dunkel withh a touch of ruby within. Its beige head is medium and collapses quickly.
Smell of caramell, molasses and yeast.
The taste begins with a mild mouthfeel, flavour’s of toffee combined with light notes of coffee, texture is medium to thin.
The aroma brings roasty, caramell, grassy and pleasant yeasty impressions along, the end is toasty/coffee-bitter, light spicy and a bit dry at last.
Light bodied and easy drinkable brew, overall a better kinded average one.
Bottle. Dark brown. Aroma has notes of bread and toasted malts. Slightly bitter taste with hints of caramel and nuts. Good creamy dunkel.
The dark malt gives a nice molasses taste to it. Feels stronger than it actually is.
50 cl bottle, pours dark amber with a decent head, aroma is light roasted, taste is slightly sweet consisting of roasted malt and coffee, abrupt finish, pretty boring.
Deep amber with a finger thick light brown head. Aroma has roasted malts, brown sugar and caramel. Toasted sweet flavor balanced with bitterness. Light to medium body. Had several of these!

Bottle. Pours a deep mahogany with a good size creamy cream coloured head. Some lacing. Big roasted malty aromas. Relatively clean and straight forward but nice all the same. Flavours are similar to the aroma with lots of malt sweetness and bitterness provided by the roasted malt. Moutfull is a little thin and watery. Pretty good beer all up.

Pours a dark brown body with a foamy tan head. Smell is malt extract and roasted buns. Taste is toast and dark malts with metallic hints mid-palate. Creamy mouthfeel. Hints of coffee in the aftertaste. A bit watery, but not too sweet. Kozel Cerny is a quite decent, albeit slightly boring lightweight dunkel on the dry side of the scale.
Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet breaddy malt and butterscotch. Flavour is sweet light roasted caramel and butterscotch.
Fantastic beer,really great flavoured and with wonderful aroma.Smooth and soft with perfect porpotions.I would definetely drink many more when I locate them in Greece!

(bottle) Clear, ruby brown colour with a medium-sized tanned foamy head. Toasty malty aroma with notes of caramel, dark bread and a delicately hoppy touch. Moderately sweet and slightly roast-bitter flavour, light bodied but not watery with a smooth carbonation. Toasty malty taste with caramel, bread crusts and dark chocolate; dry-ish, roasty bitter finish with a subtle doughy acidity. Pleasant and rounded. 07.VI.10
Tap. Color brown with medium lasting brownish head. Aroma coffee. Taste sweet roasted malt, caramel, brown sugar.

From a 500ml bottle on 5/6/2010. Has an aroma of malt, coffee and berries. Taste wise, it’s sweet, fruity and very malty, with a moderate counterbalancing bitterness. You would never guess it’s only 3.8%. Very smooth and easy to drink.
500 ml.Can Marhony colour and large fluffy beige head.Aroma is tosted with taste of caramel and nuts malty with slight metallic mouthfeels,sweet of brown sugar and malt.
50 cl bottle, Prague, Czech Republic. Translucent dark brown colour, sweet caramel aroma. Watery, some sweet toffee and mildly carbonation. Some chalk on the aftertaste.
dark amberish red pour, with a light tan head, poor retention. sweet roasty carmel aroma. l
Clear dark amber/ruby. Light tan head. Roasted malt dominant with crusty brown bread aroma. Easy in the mouth with sweet roated grains & low hop flavour. For a 3.8er it’s very good.

Pours a dark mahogany. Great light-tannish head that holds on for a little bit before leaving the lacing stuck to the side. Very bready looking head on first pour that looked like the krausen on a fermenting beer. Malty and roasty. Very nice aroma from both those attributes. Maltiness up front with a hint of roasted barley. Nice balance of the roasted flavor with the sweetness of the rest of the malts. I detect very little if any hops. But with this much maltiness and roasted flavors I would not expect to notice any hops. Velvety smooth. Silky milkiness that leaves a nice coating on the tongue after swallowing. And just like that it’s gone. But the malt still stays behind. A little residuals stay behind leaving a slight stickiness on the corners of the mouth. But don’t fault the beer for that.
Very much enjoyed this smooth and easy to drink dark beer.  It’s my go-to beer in Prague.

Tasted on different trips to Czech Republic. Pours a dark rubyred to brown peer. Very fine laced beige head. Smells sweet-malty. Full body when drinking, alcoholsweetness with some caramel. Ends in not too subtle roasted malts while the tongue is still tangling with carbon. Only a sweet aftertasts survives. A good basic beer for a night in the pub, although a little too sweet to my taste.
Bottle, Bodeguita del medio, Prague. Dark beer, big head, smooth, fullbodied with only that percebtage of alcohol. Nice, with a nice bitter in the finish.
Found this at U Fleku in Prague.  Couldn’t stop drinking the stuff.  And, at $1.50 a pint, very cost-effective.

Can. Dark brown with huge brown head. Aroma sweet, rye bread, malt. Nice. Taste roasted malts and rather sweet, again lots of rye bread notes. A nice beer and lot of taste for so little alcoholcontent.

Very dark brown, but not quite black. A tall, creamy white head. Aroma of burnt malt. Slight caramel and coffee. A touch of hops and raisins (apples?). Aroma stronger than usual. Sweetish flavor, lots of caramel, not as much roasted flavor as is in the nose. Slight burnt aftertaste, still sweet, a bit of hop dryness, but not much. Not roasted enough. Not enough hops really. A nice tasting beer, to be sure, but on the sweet end of the style. A little more like a German dunkel than is usual for a Czech dark.
bottle - clear dark brown beer with a beige head. Faint caramel aroma. Nice bread flavour, malty sweetness. Light bitterness and body. Moderate carbonation.

Brown with a fine grey head. The aroma is malt dominated with notes of roasted malts and caffe latte. The flavour is both refreshing and complex at the same time: cold caffe latte notes dominate. Excellent.

Bottle 500ml. Thin body, but enjoyable nonetheless. Aromas of burnt malt, caramel, and cola. Sweet taste, with light bitterness, and average duration. Palate is carbonated, thin and watery. Brown, with a thin frothy head.
Clear marhogny color with a thick beige head. Aroma: chocolate, malt, fruit, rye bread.Taste: bread, malt, chocolate. A little watery taste but an ok brew.

500 ml can. Finland.

Dark reddish brown colour with average quickly disappearing tan head.
Aroma is roasted malt, dry hoppiness and notes of nuts, chocolate and coffee. Roasted malt, hoppy dryness and chocolate sweetness and nuts in flavour. Quite fizzy. Good Czech Dunkel.

Andres Irish look a like brew!

Bottle, gift from Tjeck, consumed 2010-01-23 Göteborg
AR: dark suger, rosted hops
AP: dark amber colored body, fudge colored foam - lively, medium high.
F: dark suger, rosted hops, heavy carbonation, honey
A bit like New castle Brown Ale but a bit more hollow

This beer looks great - it has nice deep dark brown color with beige head. That’s exactly how good dark beer should look like. But  taste of the beer definitely fails to satisfy the promise made by the appearace. It’s flat and reveals total lack of any vision of the autors. If not vision, it would be good to have at least some idea in which direction to go. In my opinion, the beer lacks even that...

Pours brown with a fair beige head. Smells of chocolate, some roasted malt and a little grass. The taste is just a little sweet and there’s an emptiness in the middle palate. Rather like weak black iced coffee. Dull. [2.4] 

 Liked it a bit more this time - the chocolatey dark malt is nice and the fairly dry finish makes it very drinkable and just tasty enough but that empty middle is still a letdown.

Very dark brown color, beige head; aroma of sweet caramel; mouthfeel is on the thin side with some carbonation desperately trying to hold it up; very sweet flavor of syrupy caramel with hints of maltiness, but apparently the sweetness is coming from somewhere else. Use of sweetener in a beer may sound scary, but if you´re in for the bottled candy you could choose a lot worse.

Great beer. Poured a dark tan with notes of choclate and fruit in the nose. In the mouth it is smooth and refreshing and has quite a bit going on for a sub 4% beer. A little chocolate, fruit and slightly earthy flavour.

Bottle brought home from Prague, bought in Albert Supermarket: 
 


Fine, clear mahogany-brown colour. 
High, airy, foam that dissapears too quickly. The aroma is marked by obvious chocolate, caramel, some liquorice and malts. The aroma leaves no traces of the hops, but is very appealing. The flavor is quite complex with a lot of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. Some caramel appears too, and even notes of liquorice are hiding in there. The liquorice are getting more obvious towards the finish, when the beer gets more sourish and dry too. The finish is quite bitter, and fits the beer. This might sound exciting, but somehow the taste in itself still manage to give a bit of a boring impression. It might be because of the dryishness. This beer is only a little creamy, and it would suit it being more. It could be sweeter too, together with less dry. All in all this is a quite nice dunkel, though. All in all: 3.4.


 


15.05.2010: Re-rating as my brother brought by a can. Appearance is a little better this time - head lasts better, but still not long enough. Aroma is not as appealing as earlier, less complex. Else, this beer seems exactly the same as before.
Can. Brown body with a medium tan head. Fruity and light roasty aroma with some caramel. The flavour is sweet malty and light fruity with a light hoppy character.

(draught 0,5l)
Brown color. Creamy brown all time head. Light caramel aroma. Caramel taste. Medium sweet, light sour. Light sweet end.
Bottle. Poured brown with a ivory head that laced a bit. Aroma was sweet with notes of caramel malts. Flavor was more grainy, but the caramel malts were still present. The body was a bit light.
Bottle. Amber dark color body with nice, brownish head. Round caramel and malty taste. Sweet caramel aroma. Some bitterness.

Bottle. Pours dclear and dark brown with a red glow with a huge beige head.  Fair lacing. Nose of light malt. Sweet flavour with malt and bread. Light to medium bodied. More dry finish with a little bitterness.

Pours with almost no head, and what does exist disappears very quickly. Smells like coffee and water, maybe some grape juice in there too. Taste is coffee, coffee, coffee - very surprising for this brew, but it lacks complexity and feels a little bit fake. On the other hand, there are worse flavours to imitate and it’s an okay "fake" dark beer. Worth trying if you can get it for free.

(bottle) Poured perfectly, a deep ruby-brown colour with ample head.
For a beer of only 3.8% alc/vol this one had plenty of body.  There was a definite roastiness present, and the hopping was spot on.  This is one I could come back to many times if available.

on tap - Prague. My beer of preference during my stay in Prague. Dark ruby color, nice head. Sweet caramel taste, light body, refreshing. I found this to be an excellent session beer given the alcohol content and light - medium body.

Canned. Dark ruby brown, medium-sized off-white head. Toasted rye bread aroma, little salmiak. Flavor has slight licorice, sweet roasty rye bread, molasses, slight coal and metal in the finish. Light to medium bodied, a tad coarse carbonation, some sugariness on the palate. I hate the saccharine, but have to admit that this is still pretty alright flavourwise.

bottle.  train rating.  moderately creamy texture, overall pretty good for bottled dunkel but of course doesn’t match fresh draft anything.  toffee, coffee cake, toast, all there but with an oily butter and metal note.  taste some bottle and bottle cap in there.
50 cl can. aroma is sweet, caramel. flavour almost too sweet, Very easy to drink, refreshing if served cold. Medium body.
Bottle. Dark red amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, toffee, prunes. Flavour is sweet, malt, hint of hop, roasted malt, prunes. Medium to thin body. Boring beer.
Drought beer, in Belarus. Frothy, light brown head; lightly sweet flavor, moderately hoppy, medium body and lightly acidic finish. Love it!

12.09.2009, 0,5l Bottle. Colour is dark brown with off-white head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt. This beer is very sweet. The malty sweetness is not backed up by bitterness and alcohol, so its maybe a little bit off-balanced.

Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is smoke dark malts and chocolate. Flavor is roasted grains dark malts chocolate, and a touch of choco malt coffee bitterness. Creamy body and easy to drink. Decent Dunkel.
Bottle - Very Dark red with a creamy off white head. Sweet aroma, initial thought was molasses, hint of malt.  Roasted malt flavour not as sweet as i was expecting from the aroma.

500 ml bottle. Clear, dark reddish brown body with a firm tan head. Aroma is sweet malt and caramel. Flavor is sweet malty with slightly roasted caramel and slightly bitter. Smooth, uncomplicated, easy drinkable relatively flavorful concerning low alcohol level, quite refreshing served cold and just a bit too much on the sweeter side.

Draught, Dublin. Pours dark ochre, with beige and compact head, that eventually dissipates to quarter-finger deep. Nutty aroma of sweet malts, and something similar on the palate but with caramel notes. Put me in mind of Smithwicks, the Irish ale.

Sampled in Prague. A pretty good brew. Got to love the goat. Color is dark brown, a rarity in Prague. Has a pretty good thick head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Palate is pretty crisp with not to much carbonation. A very good brew.
Dark. Not amazing, but pretty solid. You could definitely do a lot worse when beer touring the Czech Republic and it helps break the monotony of the numerous Pilsners.

Biggish yellowish beige head. Dark red translucent body. Burnt earthy milky licorice aroma with toffee and straw notes, quite harmonic. Dry-sweetish roasty earthy metallic licorice taste with chocolatey notes. Mid-bodied. Slightly watery mouthfeel. Dry roasty licorice and straw aftertaste. Quite nice, but a tad too watery. Would be great unfiltered. (0.5l bottle, Meny, Oslo.)

Pours dark reddish brown with a few mm’s of light brown head. Aroma is earthy, roasted notes, caramel, nuts. Flavours are more caramel, subtly roasted notes and chocolate, light grassy hops in the finish. Not much complexity, but a nice beer. Loads of flavour for the low abv, and as expected, a bit thin.

(draught, at U Pietasu, Pilsen) clear dark ruby colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of coffee, dark chocolate and fruits. flavour is the same, with some spicy, fruity dark malts. medium carbonation and body.

500 ml bottle. Red dark copper with black notes. Fine-laced off-white head. Light slightly burnt caramel aroma. Sweet flavours with plums and dark sugars. More of the burnt caramel in the flavour. High carbonation level. Sweet fizzy and light bodied. Not a particularly good beer.

(Bottle (50cl) and from tap) I think I prefer it from tap, but the bottled version was also good. Tried i several times (from tap) before i found out that it was only 3,8%. It was a big suprise, full rich taste with such alcohol content. To bad it’s so expensive in Norway.
Bottle 50 Cl. Apperance; dark brown, clear with a medium lightbrown head. Aroma; lot of caramel, roasted malt and some nuts. Flavor, sweet caramel and malt. Sweet aftertaste, quite nice.

500 ml bottle from Centra Colloseum, Oslo.
Fully diminshing tan head. Clear, dark brown colored body. Sweet smelling; dark bread and nutty malts. No hops included. Sugar-sweet and  mellow malt flavor. Notes of burnt sugar, sugar-diluted coffee and milk-chocolate. Still no hops, even not for balancing. Body is light plus. Mouthfeel is not that bad, a bit juicy. Brown sugar ending. Not for me, this one.
coffee, chocolate, brown, clear, white foam, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, I prefer more bitterness dark bier
Mine was 3.2% ABV. Dark brown, almost no head. Light coffee aroma, Chocolate/coffee palate, slightly bitter. A beer for every season.

On tap at U Cerneho Vola, Prague.
Deep amber, almost black with a large off white creamy head. Roasted aroma with traces of liquorize and caramel. Sweet taste of malt, coffee. Smooth and easy drinkable.
bottle, pours deep amber, tall frothy white head.  Coffee, alcohol, and honey nose.  Soft light carbonation, creamy dark malt, sweet coffee, and a light spiced finish.  A good lager.

50cl bottle from føtex, hillerød
pours dark brown with a rather small light brown head.
slightly roasted, slightly buttery, sweeitsh aroma.
flavor is sugar-sweet, roasted caramel, malts. the chzeck budweiser dark i had yesterday was WAY better than this one.
500ml Bottle - Dark brown with red tinges. Lightly roasted aroma with hints of fruit and coffee. Lightly roasted taste with hints of coffee and root beer, followed by some coffee notes in the finish.

Draft at Zythos Restaurant in Athens. Very dark red color with a firm rich head. Malty flavor andaroma with hints of coffee , caramel. Medium bitter finish. Very nice and drinkable despite being that light !

Sep 11, 2007  
Bottle at Praha airport. Creamy. Dark brown colour. Sugary and malty taste. Some nut and roast notes. Smooth and enjoyable. My 12th and last Czech beer this weekend.

500ml bottle. It is a good example of a Czech ladies beer ie. a mid strength dark lager. The appearance is of a red brown cloudy liquid with a short lasting creamy off white head. Caramel malts on the nose. Palate reminded me of a caramel cafe late with a subtle bitterness in the finish. Medium bodied. Smooth and very drinkable.
Bottle. Poured very muddy like. Reddish brown in colour - almost black. Rocky head which was a light off brown colour. Heavy malt flavourwith a medium body.
On tap in Prague. Dark brown colour, beige head. Aroma of moccha, malts, caramel. Flavour is sweet, malty, caramel, moccha/coffee. Rather fullbodied for such a light beer, but a bit too sweet for me.
<i>Bottled. </i> Dark brown, rich firm head. Aroma of coffee and caramel. Sweet and medium bodied with rounded mouthfeel. Caramelly salty finish.
From tap, Dark reddish liquid with creamy head, aroma of malt and high sweetness, flavors of coffee and milk with sweet (maybe too sweet) aftertaste, Impressive beer.
50 cl bottle at Skallerup Klit. Brown reddish color with a nice beige head. Aroma is roasted malt and sweetness. Flavor is roasted and caramel malt - sweet. Nice, but a bit thin and watery.

Not bad. Highly drinkable - it goes down very easy. It has a low alcohol content of 3.8%, but doesn’t taste watery like many similar strength brews. Rather, the flavour is allowed to shine without too much alcoholic influence. A little bit sweet, but with a pleasantly dark and malty follow-through. All in all a very good beer.

500ml can

Deep reddy brown, bready head. Smell is a bit metallic. Quite watery palate, but a decent enough burnt maltiness to it. Very restrained hops. A little sweet, but some samples we’ve had have been very sweet - quality control’s not their strong point. Quite drinkable, but not very exciting.
500ml bottle. Black coloured, semithick light brown head. Aroma is mild with sweet roasted malts. Flavor is roasted malts, somewhat watery. Some btiterness at the end.

500ml on tap in a bar in Prague. Near black in colour with reddish tones and a foamy tan head. Caramel and toffee aroma. Flavour was very sweet, with a touch of fruit and milk chocolate and demerara sugar in the finish. Ok.

On draught. An almost black colored beer, with a beige head. The aroma of caramel sweet, malty and a little hop. The taste of caramel sweet, a little chocolate but watery. As aftertaste the caramel sweetness stays for a while.
Can. Reddish brown colour with a tan head. Sweet malty aroma. The flavour is sweet, roasted malt. Slightly bitter finish. Light to medium-bodied and easy to drink.

500ml bottle. Muted nose packed with malt; particular roasted nuttiness about it, some caramel sweetness, dark chocolate and a subtle woody vinous fruitiness lingering in the background.
Pours a nice deep bronze body highlighted with red. Offwhite medium head leaves solid lace. 
Moderate carbonation, the palate isn’t too lengthy but it has a good malt stickiness that lends the body a bit of extra fullness than you’d expect from the abv.
Plenty of malt on the body, quite sweet overall; chocolate, cereal, caramel, brown sugar, cola, some dried fruit and woodiness. Finish is drying with a slight gritty bitterness.
Nice, simple, easy, flavoursome dark lager, bit on the sweet side.
on tap. 1st beer in Prague. Reddish brown pour. Aroma is malty sweet with a light floral presence. Taste  has a cola like sweetness. MaltyLight bodied. Average beer

I had this beer on tap in Prague, and thoroughly enjoyed it. The nose is a sweet smoke, pouring deep brown with a rich caramel head and complex body of caramel and butterscotch, a touch of hardwood smoke, a touch of brown sugar and a slight splash of whiskey.
Red brownish colour. Pale brown head. Some hints of syrup and malts in the nose. Maltiness and licorice aromas in the taste. A mild and a bit sweet taste. A 0.5l can from local shop.

(Draught) Pours very dark reddish brown. The aroma is malty and a medium to full sweet with notes of brown sugar, raisins, buttery fudge and cookies alongside some hints of hops (maybe a touch of grass and herbs). The flavour is medium sweet with tones of dark, sugary fudge alongside grassy and earthy hops. The finish is hop dryish with burned sugar/caramel sweetness. The mouthfeel is light crisp. Light to medium bodied.

...bottle.  Nice dark beer, with an off-white, lasting head.  Smooth, malty, grainy, goes down well.  No overpowering alcohol taste, which is not typical of the style.  Slightly sweet, but not over the top, balanced by roasted malt with a nice smooth finish, and a hint of hops.  Surprisingly good, but overpriced due to the low alcohol content.
Pours beautyful nutty-golden with a nice big offwhite head. Aroma is yeasty, hoppy and slightly roasted. It is very malty sweet and without carbonation - almost caramelised...
On tap @ The Military Club, Plzen. Brown in colour with a medium sized head. Malty with notes of sugar, grain and hops.

Pours a four finger light tan head that fades very slowly leaving a good lace. Clear, deep mahogany color. Light carbonation and light-medium bodied.  Malty nose. Flavor is sweet malty with hops in background. 500ml bottle €5.20 on M/S Silja Symphony ferry between Stockholm and Helsinki. From my notes - 7/8/2008.

On tap on 6/28 (forget the name of the place, but it was right outside of Prague castle in the middle of a small vineyard)  Morning beer my first day in Prague right outside of Prague castle with a beutiful view of the city.  The beer was sweet, but also clear and refreshing.
Tap in the militery bar. Alround rating: Its kozel with cola and caramel added, do i need to say any more?

500 ml bottle. Dark reddish brown colour, small light brown head. Aroma of sweet dark bread and roasted malts. The flavour is also sweet, with some roasted malts and a lightly bitter finish. I used to think this is an excellent beer, but now I find it merely OK..

Canned. Dark, reddish brown liquid and blond beige head. Malty aroma is slightly roasted and has rye bread. Some hops in the finish. Flavor is sweet syrupy turning to a bit sour and bitter in the finish. Smooth but    somewhat watery mouthfeel. Light bodied and too heavily carbonated. Easy to drink, but very simple and boring. Anyway,  this was the beer that made me taste many more.
White head on a brown-red body. Sweeter than I expected, some hops, hints of roasted malts. Not the best, but drinkable.
Roasted malts, sweet sugar and syrup in aroma. Flavor is sweet, roasty and sugary, only tiny amount of hops.
(Bottle on 2008-06-11) Dark reddish brown. Clear. Small white head. Malty sweet nose. Sugary palate with some carbonation. Tiny amount of hops. Syrup. Hints of burned malts.  Boring and too sweet.

draught at Woolpack Vantaa 080508
Color:dark brown nice head
Scent:sweet dark malts
Taste:bit hops,sweet roasted malts. But no aftertaste at all.
This was my re-minder. I was total lager girl 12 years ago. I interested in about other beers through this and Guinness...

Cheap dark lager from Prague Tesco - 25p. It’s malty sweet. The low abv keeps it light and clean and the carbonation cuts through the sweetness. But it’s a lifeless and characterless beer. Drinkable enough, but not great.

50 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a deep amber glare. Slowly diminishing off-white head. Medium sweet breadish aroma. Flavour is sweet and mild fruity with a light breadish touch. Dry malt base into the finish. Light acidic note too.
Bottle 0.5 l. Bought Føtex Frederikssund. Dark brown color wth beige soft head. Mild malty aroma. Taste sweet malt. Soft carbonation. Soft prickling mouthfeel.

It was brewed by a giant brewer, and that trust in Hungary brews bad stuffs. And i was dissapointed! Good stuff, drinkable one. Dark brown body under a foamy and delisicious beige head. Sweet buttery aroma of roasted malt. Fine sweet flavour of toffe, roasted malt, lively carbonation. Good, drinkable, positive:)

Dark, rich brown color. Slight head, light brown in color. Quite sweet with hints of chocolate and caramel (maybe even a little coffee or something). Sweet, malty flavor. Unfortunately, tonight is my last night in Prague so I probably won’t get to try one of these again for a while. Perhaps I’ll have one tomorrow morning before my flight. That sounds like a great idea.
500 ml can. Pours a very deep brown with an attractive dark head. Aroma of chocolate malt. Taste of sweet malts and light chocolate. Very sweet, low on bitterness.
Dark brown, roasted malt aroma with notes of caramel and hops. Sweet malt flavour and mild bitterness.
The can seems to cause a metallic taste. Too much sweetness to be enjoyable.
50cl bottle. Pours dark amber with a creamy off white head. Very malty - caramel, toffee & ryebread - quite sweet. Medium filling body. Enjoyable!
Had a bottle at the Prague airport. Didn’t get to pour it into a glass... nice dark brew. Spicy on the palate with a good malt background.
Very dark brown color with a slightly foamy top. Both aroma and flavor are a bit too sweet, but otherwise good for a dunkel.
Dark brown colour, brown head. Aroma is malty and sweet. Flavour has roasted malts and caramel. Average.

Rated:24.05.2007

Bottle 500 ml, brown, extract of wort 10%

Dark amber, wattery, red to dark red or even beown,. Head is quite long lasting and grey, carbonation is weak. Flavour is of malts and sweet caramell plus some additional artificial sweetness; quite wattey, Munich malts, no hoppy aroma.

dark brown with big head
watery and very uniteresting in every aspect. too bulk to me

Back from a Czech Republic pub-crawl this is part of my express ratings for the “typical” Světlý 11°- (Czech light Pils), Světlý 12°+ (Czech Pils), Polotmavý (Czech Amber Lagers) and Tmavý (Czech Black Lagers).  Non-typical beers will receive personalized descriptions after the express ratings.
----------------------------------------------------------------

How: Tap in some non-beer-geek restaurant in Karlovy Vary, Czech Republic

The look: Dark brown body with a medium beige head

To me a typical Czech Tmavé (Czech Black Lager) is: Dark malts and barely any roastiness sensation.  Some dark fruits flavours (raisins with a little figs, dates and prunes) wrapped in smooth dark caramel (borderline toffee) and a subtle chocolate note.  A bit bready.  Moderately sweet without much hops presence and only a mild bitterness (voluntary unbalanced it seems).  Very smooth body, like a watery cream.

This one: As above but a bit sweeter (too sweet) and syrupy than average with some liquorice flavours.  Something felt “artificial” about it.  Inferior Tmavý.
Canned. Medium brown colour, thick beige head. Sweet, sugary aroma with malt. Taste sugar and roasted amlt. Quite full for its strength.
draught at Plzensky Dvur Smichov. Dark bwon colour, large and very very creamy head. Sweet and malty, full-bodied, hints of roasted malt and caramel. Slightly hoppy only. Surprisingly good.

Bottle. Clear dark red brown, fluffy lasting light brown head. Mild sweet aroma. This used to be a favorite but now it tastes just candy sweet with a bit of roasted malt. Good malty and a bit hoppy finish. I suspect artificial sweetener. Average dunkel.

Bottle. High fluffy but lasting light brown head. Very dark clear red brown body. Roasted barley malt aroma with a bit of caramel and notes of butter. Very sweet and mild roasted barley malt flavor with caramel. Low carbonation and a short sweet aftertaste.

3.8%??! Tap, all over Prague. Ruby tints and beige lace. Sweet malty chocolatey sessions. Cocoa Pops milk with dunked butter cookie. Simple, sweet, beautiful late morning/lunchtime beer...almost a drainpour by evening...way too sweet to be serious. Dark malts beaten to death with the sugarspoon. Overly saccharine tasty restorative.
Aroma is very sweet and malty. It looks dark brown with a beige head - good lasting. The flavor is very sweet and a lot of malt characteristics.
Dark brown with medium off white head. Aroma is sweet with caramel and malty notes. Sweet caramel flavor with metallic notes. Ends watery.
Dark and malty and the flavour is sweet, but not cloying, and it has notes of caramel. It’s easy to drink but it could have more depth. (Early rating, and too short)
The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass also. Fine foam. The beer is modest malty, a little bit sweet, not penetrating. Not bad, good beer!

Pours a medium brown hue with burgundy highlights and a thin, off-white, frothy head.  The nose is robust with powdered cocoa, toast and weak coffee.  A faint woodsy hoppiness makes its way in from behind.  Moderately sweet on the tongue, elements of smoke and butter come forth in shy quantities.  Slick and fairly clean, though there’s a bit of acidic prickling in the finish.  Nutty aftertaste, cashews perhaps.  Medium bodied with lively carbonation and a watery texture.  Quite sessionable and interesting.  50cl can, goblet.
very appetizing..very flavorful, available in abundence in Prague...IMPOSSIBLE TO FIND IN THE UNITED STATES :(

Bottle, 50cl. The beer is darkbrown with an off-white head. The aroma is caramel and a little roasted. Taste is sweet and caramel, with notes of roasted malts. Great beer to put out the thirst, but not so good with food. Overall an average dunkel.

Draught at Cross Club, Prague.   Clear dark red/brown with a beige head that laces.   Sweet aroma with a hint of roast.   The flavor is similarly sweet with some toffee; very candy-ish.   The body is medium thin and over-carbonated.   An easy drinker with no bad flavors, but its just a little boring and simple to keep any interest.   Nice to see on tap at a night club though.
Nice, dark czech beer. Taste is quite sweet, with syrup or caramel taste. Can’t drink really many of these and don’t mix with food for ex., ok overall
Pours an amber brown color with an off white head.  Aroma is malty sweet, with hints of caramel.  Flavor is malty sweet, has hints of dark fruit, and a light bitter finish.

Darkest of reds,tan head not lasting.Aroma cooked earthy malt a slight sweet rich smell.Flavour a bit metallic not that malty,burnt hop flavour leaves a slight velvet taste (nutty)good for thirst.Perfect carbonation for a dark beer.Igot the colour by having a light the other side of the glass.

Bottle. Clear dark brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light brown head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, brown sugar, dark bread. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (191107)
Overall an good flavoured beer. It’s light in alcohol so very drinkable. First it’s mainly sweet roasted malts, but the aftertatse is dry, and delicate bitter.

Pours dark brown with a reddish tint around the edges. Medium beige head with fair retention. Stringy lacing. Light roasted malt and bread in the nose, with touches of fruit. Medium (bordering thin at times) smooth body with sweet caramel malt flavor along with dry fruit and rye. The finish is short and fruity with a lingering sweetness. Solidly average Dunkel all around.

[Sampled in 2004. DK-Bulgaria: 2-0.] Great look of dark brew and a tasty aroma of sweet caramelmalts added with brown sugar. More sweet than average makes this beer good for summernights, but too sweet and thin for food.

Draft @ U Vejvodu, Prague.  Pours dark brown with foamy tan head, rather sweet and treacly on the nose, a strong hazelnutty character too, solid body with notes of brown sugar, very little hoppiness at any stage, hardly bitter.  Slight oxidation.  Quite quaffable.
30cl draft in Prague airport: poured brown with a beige head. Mild caramel, bread notes. Flavor is light caramel. Somewhat watery finish. Easy drinking. I could handle a few of these. Not bad.
500 ml bottle.  Clear brownish color.  Medium carbonation.  Sweet molasse taste.
One of my favorite beers... taste is so smooth... Had this when I was in Prague.
Flaske. Mørkebrun. Duft af sukker som også går igen i smagen. Men meget drikbar især grundet de lidt færre procenter.
Bottle... I just didn’t get it. THe flavor doesn’t hold up for me. A bit too watery.
Bottle, on the train to Denmark. Purposeful brown, coarse tan head. Clean brown bread aroma, a bit earthy. Toasty brown bread flavor, a bit of chocolate.
Bottle at Praha airport. Creamy. Dark brown colour. Sugary and malty taste. Some nut and roast notes. Smooth and enjoyable. My 12th and last Czech beer this weekend.

Bottle. Bought @ Føtex, Aabenraa. Golden ruby-red (quite dark) with a medium, slightly fizzy, foamy yellowish head. Aroma is nutty with a little roasted malts. Flavour is sweet, nutty and mixing in a little chocolate and roasted flavours. Nice flavour, but the mouthfeel is perhaps a little limited.

Purchased this 500 ml bottle in Praha a couple of months for next to nothing and drank this past weekend in Dublin.

Pour resulted in a nice head that didn’t stay around too long on a brown copper body that looks great.

Very malty and very sweet are the first aromas that hit your nose after the pour. Some nutty flavors come through next.

The malts, nuts, and sweetness all come through on the first sip and there is a bit of coffee to it too. Goes down really smooth-full of flavor yet not too heavy so that is a nice combination. I do agree that the taste doesn’t stick around too long in the mouth and on the tongue, but the mouthfeel is great with a bit of carbonation.

I was impressed by this beer and have not had alot of this style before so I would like to try more now. I would definitely try some if I saw it here in Ireland or if I go back to Praha.

[i]Bottle at the Bishops Arms, V Hamngatan, Göteborg, Sweden.[/i] Dark clear reddish borwn with a small beige head. Nutty and toffeish aroma, slightly roasted. Light to medium bodied, decent mouthfeel. Flavour is too sweet.

Very dark ruby red with thin off white head. Metallic aroma. Rather smooth texture, fruit, liquorice flavour. Initial quite sweet, brown sugar. Seems to go more thin as you drink it and loses it flavour a little, which is a shame.  Overall disappointing by the end, a bit thin gassy.
Dunkel style beer, found in a supermarket in Greece. Sweet with dark foam and a bit of smokey taste. Better than other Chech beers
Not much of a selection on a Czech train ride.  Ah well, at least it’s beer.  And I’m also really glad its "foam" is dark, too.
I liked this - it was quite sweet, but not as much so as one may expect.  Had a little smokey kind of taste, which made it interesting.

Clear brown/red look with a nice baige dense head. Classic dunkel aroma of fermented fruits, a little bit of toasted bread and sweet malts. Flavor is again mainly sweet and soft, with a bit of roasted bitterness. Palate is smooth and soft, highly drinkable.
Pours a dark brown colour. Tan head. A decent dunkel tasted today in Prague. Roasty on the side.
Draught in St Petersburg, Russia.  Blackish brown beer with a light head.  The aroma is sweet malts, and the flavour is sour, vinous and malty.  Overall an alright vinous and sour beer.

(Bottle, Monk’s Café, Stockholm) Mahogany brown colour with huge, beige head, leaving some lacing. Malty, rather sweet nose with notes of dried fruit, brown sugar, caramel and wort bread. Malty, grainy taste with sweetish notes of brown sugar and dark rye bread. Not very bitter, slightly below medium body, rather sweet. Very tasty considering the low abv. Nice.
Beer 88 Summer 2006 trip in Europe.  Drank on 7/18/06 in dining car on the way to Berlin from Prague.  light dunkel oh not great.
Bottle in Russia. Dark brown in color with roasted notes both within the aroma and the taste. Also hints of sweetness from fruit and toffee flavors. Best beer I had while in Russia

Draft in old town Prague.  This is a fine beer.  Tan head in large mouthed mug.  Lightly fruity nose with some roastyness. Light in body for the darker color.  Sweet and lightly caramelish. Some grassyness.  Great on a hot day tramping accross Prague.  Fortunatly for me they had this beer strategically placed along my 6.5 mile walking route.  Perfect in Prague.
From tap: a little roasty, pretty sweet, nice maltyness, mainly caramel, some wet wood, some rye(?), dry finish, pretty stale and weak tasting, not impressive.
Bottle. Clear dark reddish colour with medium creamy white mostly diminishing head. Roasted malty aroma. Sweet flavor.
Prague-07.  Black-red colour with low head. Has some nice malt notes, but could use much more.
Dark brown colour, big creamy head. Nice body, slightly sweet with caramel notes. Quite light as a dunkel but tasty.
Bottle (500ml) in Prague near the castle. Clear dark (CocaCola) - offwhite head. Ryebread, sweetness, dried fruits, chokolate, malty, roasted, dry burned, raisins. Nice.

Bottle. Large fizzy beige head that mostly diminished. Good lacing. Clear slightly dark brown colour. Nice light roasted malty note, light butter, caramel, dry fruit, liquorish and some candies notes as well. Light to medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Flavour was light to moderated sweet, not much burned malty bitterness. Finish was sweet.

nice dark brown body with quite stable head, medium lacing, aroma is sweet smoked malts, caramel, but the taste was poor, no roast, no smoke, strange hop bitterness in the backgroung, like fruit tea with thin dunkel
Nice malty taste with hints of licorice, body is quite thin but it doesn’t matter. Mouthfeel is a bit carbonated and bitter, aftertaste is slightly sour.
Very nice smooth bock-like pivo with nice malty character.  This dark beer featured a light hop aroma overtaken by its abundant dark malt flavor.

One of the oddest ratings I scored ever. Had it draught at a party at my university’s student club. They usually serve just Pilsner Urquell draught, but they also had this on yesterday. Poured a nice dark (almost black) red colour, with a thick, creamy medium sized beige head that went away slowly. The aroma was pleasant, a sweetish, malty nose with a few hints of hops. The taste was quite one dimensional, but that one dimension was damn pleasant. A soft, sweet malty taste, caramel, hints of hops (Saaz I reckon). Sweetish aftertaste. A lovely light dunkel.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a nice beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, fruit, caramel, chocolate and hops.

bottle into long glass (wiezen glass)

dark fruit/sweet aroma.
dark ruby color.
light crystal malt, almost fruity flavour.
clean palate, goes down very well.

might become overly sweet if drunk to much.

Draught, beautifull dark colour but not to opaque, just the right amount of sweetness. complex flavours of chocolate. smooth. long aftertaste.
wonderfull brew.

Re-rate 1/16/08: Bottle. Dark reddish brown with a medium, quickly disappearing, off-white head. Malty aroma with toasted bread and hints of milk chocolate. Sweet toasted malt flavor with caramel, light hoppy bitterness in the finish. A bit watery. OK, but definitely lacks in character and not as good as I remembered it. 6/3/5/2/11=2.7


Bottle. Dark brown with a pretty big beige head. Lightly roasted malt and some caramel in the nose. Flavor is nice sweet malt which finishes with a bit of hop bitterness. A light to medium body. A nice dunkel. 6/4/6/3/13=3.2

Oh goody a bottle with medals on it, wait a minute it hasn’t got one from AIBA, sh*t everyone gets one of them - even Outback Brewery got one for having pretty labels - not a good start.
Now on to the beer - pours a neat red-brown w/- a big rocky head. Aroma is dominated by caramel upfront followed by stone fruit (plums) and a touch of cinimmon (sp). Flavour is sparse and sweet mostly caramel maltishness. What is there is quite good but is sooo watered down it loses the plot. More malt & alcohol please! Still as a mid-strenght beer if you’re driving it beats most of the sh*t we brew and drink over here. Cheque please.
red brown beer with a cloudy liquid. medium bitterness. Not my type of beer, to much bitterness. I like more golden beer like spanish and dutch beer.
Bottle. Dark brownish colour with an average bubbly head. Sweet caramel and roasty aroma. Flavour is rather sweet, some roasted maltiness, bit hoppy. Sweet aftertaste.
500ml bottle (Easy to drink.. And a realy nice appearace. Its a OK lager frome Czech

5o cl bottle. Ruby/brown, fine head. A bit sweet, rather thin and watery at first, but it get a bit more of a body after a while. But you hardly expect a lager drinker to wait until the beer is warm, do you?
Sweet tasting and reddish color with a rocky head. Tight and firm tasting, not bad for style. Well made lager.
Good czech dunkel, maybe a bit too sweet for my taste. You can get this from almost any supermarket in Finland.

Bottle: Reddish-amber coloured, creamy tanned head, slowly diminishing to a small stable foamy layer; sweet-malty, toasted-malty nose; sweet-caramelly flavour, light bodied, soft MF; toasted, caramelly finish with a small chocolatey bitterness in the end. Hearty, easily drinkable Dunkel, a bit on the sweet side....

Pours a dark mahogany from the tap, nice read hue to it, with a smooth off-white head. Didn’t have the roastiness that many other dunkels i’ve had in Prague showed. Malts show more of a caramel and molasses note. Very smooth on the palate and nice balance.

Lys brun øl fået på fad på ferie i Prag

Sødlig karamel smag og lidt humlet

Meget drikkevenlig.

karamel duft

Perfekt kulsyreniveau

courtesy of oh6gdx - dark ruby brown colour, little irregular but stable beige head; slightly toasted, a fair biscuity maltiness and some caramelish notes; quite sweet and light-bodied with a solid carbonation; short butterscotchy aftertaste

Nice dark beer. Sweet flavour coming from the beer rather than from the alcohol. Really creamy and all, but seriously lacking any semblence of alcohol. For some reason, beers with not enough alcohol annoy me a little, I think I kind of like the taste. Tastes really good when made a black and tan with Pilsner Urquell.

On tap at The Kolkovna, Prague, Pasteurised, 500ml. Dark brown with malty cream head. The ubiquitous Kozel dark can be found at any of the hundreds of Pilsner Urquell bars around Prague, I have to say that Sandra loves this beer, but I find it much too sweet for me, there is licorice in there and a certain fruitiness, but really the sweetness is overwhelming.

Clear brown with a decent sized beige head that last a little while and then faded away. Syrupy chocolate aroma with a touch of licorice and caramelised nuts. On first taste the caramel comes barrelling in, but because of the low abv it seems to saturate quickly and isn’t as present in subsequent mouthfulls. Light bodied, again because of the abv. Good carbonation peps it up a little while still being very drinkable. Nice, sweet aftertaste that seems to satisfy. However, IMHO, with some more bollocks this could be a very good beer, but as it is it is just good.

A very unique flavor for this czech beer. A friend recently visited Finland and brought back this little gem. I must say for such a low abv. it had a solid taste. If I had to compare it to a beer in the states I would say its alot like drinking Modelo Negra but with an extreme caramel flavor. Good finish. Very smooth and sweet. If you are ever able to try "Double Goat" beer, I think you should.
Amber with an offwhite head. Aroma is malty and slightly floral. Full roast malt flavour with some sweetness, although the taste gets dryer in the roasted.

On tap. Quite interesting, best Czech dunkel I’ve tried perhaps. Sarsparilla with a weird caramel aftertaste. Have since tried it bottled a few times, where the nice balance of the sweet flavours seems to go out of whack and turn into a sickly mess that’s sometimes hard to finish.

Bottle 0,5l. Dark brown. A large light brown creamy head. Lasring for a while. Sweet aroma of malt and caramel. Caramel dominating the flavour. Some sweet bitterness in the finish.  A good beer, but a bit unvaried.

dark brown,....dark red under a lamb color, foamy not lasting head, the best dark/czech I ever had with less than 4% alc ..Malty aroma with notes of caramel and hops. The flavour is dominated by malt with some sweetnes and metallic notes.. Slightly bitter finish

Great looking beer, copper with a creamy rocky brown head. OK lacing and retention. Lots of caramel in the aroma, with a tiny bit of yeast. The body is a little thin as expected, but shows some reasonable balance and the caramel flavours are very complex. These flavours continue in the finish, rounding off a good beer, perhaps it could be a little more bitter.

The first of september, the dark season starts. I pick a Kozel Cerny what I bought on my vacation in the Czech Republic. This beer is dark and good, could be a bit more bitter. But I like this kind of beer.
Draught. Clean caramelly flavours. Fairly sweetish. Boring and a poor beer overall.

500ml can bought at small convenience store in Helsinki, Finland.  Murky brown in colour, large tan coloured head, good retention, some lacing.  The aroma is slightly metallic, some dark malts, cookies and bread.  The flavour has a mild roastiness, some light burnt malts, toasty, mild dark chocolate, nutty.  Mild bitter mouthfeel, medium/light body, medium carbonation.  Finishes clean, malty and short.  Not to bad at all, to bad this isn’t available where I live because I’d have this again.

Nice looking 500ml bottle and label. Creamy, beige head over an appealing deep mahogany and scarlet gown. Dark malty aroma. Watery. Medium bodied. Brittle caramel flavour with grainy notes. More sweetness and some yeastiness in the finish. Becomes far too sweet half way through the glass.
500ml bottle.  Large initial head, dark brown appearance.  Toasty malt aroma.  Smooth, nutty, chocolate tastes.  Very sweet, also too much so.  Slightly unpleasant after taste.

Dark brown, amber hue, tan smallish head. Aroma: Medium dark toasted malts with sweeter malts below, mild clean hop character. Medium bodied m smooth texture with light smoky finish. Very soft, smooth brew. A bit to plain over all.

A nice dark, thanks to Radek bought in Poland. Wine brandy colour, bit of lace. Licorice, bit sour, despite malting including caramel. Tad chocolate malt as well. Bit of roast. Not complex, easy drink. A particular dunkel style, OK but not that I seek out.

First rating
Draught 50 cl at "Zizkovsky restaurant Olse" in Zizkov in Prague.
Rating added 5/28/2006
Deep dark reddish to brown color with a brownish head. Hoppy and a bit sour scent. Rich body, medium bitterness. Sweet and refreshing taste.
Pure heaven compared to the bottled version you can find in Sweden!
8/4/8/4/18=4.2

Second rating
(500 ml bottle at the Plzen train station)
Clear dark brown color, tan head. Sweet malty and roasted scent. Sweet malty fruity taste. Medium mouthfeel. Low bitterness.
7/4/7/3/13=3.4

Rerate
Draught at Na Farme, outside of Praha, on June 6, 2011
Clear dark brownish red color, off-white head. sweet, malty, sugary taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness. Sweet, roasted scent.
7/4/7/3/14=3.5

Rerate
Sampled on August 2, 2017.
At U Černého Vola, Praha.
From tap.
Slight hazy dark brown color, tan fluffy head with lacing. Sweet, malty, sugary taste. Slight roasted, mainly sweet aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness. Sweet, malty, slight roasted scent.
6/4/6/3/12=3.1
(Tap) An OK sweet flavored dunkel. At times, it was almost too sweet for my liking. Caramel and toffee notes. Brown body, with beige head. A little unbalanced, but tasty if you like a sweeter beer.

Aroma/Malty-toasted,
Appearance Head/Initial-frothy, Head/Color light brown,
Body/Hue-brown,
Initial Flavor-sweet light
Finish Flavor-sweet light
Palate/Body-medium to full
beer
50cl bottle. Ruby chestnut colour with thin beige head. Roasted toffee aroma, coffee and quite sweet. Thinnish in mouth with more toffee/coffee. Finish has more of the same. Fine if a tad sweet.
a smoothe thick and dark body topped with a quality head of foam. My favorte dunkel.

This is an excellent dunkel and session beer.  The beer is dark brown and has a very thick head.  Aroma has malt and carmel, as well as fruit.  Sweet flavor that includes more malt and carmel.  Lightly hopped.  Outstanding palate.  Smooth and exceptionally easy to drink.

Not so much to say about this fantastic invention - it’s just so wonderful, both in the aspects of taste, flavour and aroma but appearance and palate too. If I had to choose a beer to drink every day, this one would surely be situated in the top 3... fantastically made!

Bottled:
Light sweetish aroma.
Head with big bubbles, dark brown. Sweetish, not exiting flavor, quite light bodied. Light dry, empthy end.
Pours golden with a white head. Very (too) sweet. Lacks sourness and bitterness. Lots of caramel aromas.

Keg
Dark amber color. Light aroma of malt, caramel, fudge. Weak body, with a sweetish taste, almost just caramel, and not bitter enough.
Bottle. Dark with a fast disappearing head. Light malty, slighty fruity aroma.  Short finish. Not much for hops. Refreshing

Bottled. Looks good, this brown beer with a small beige head. Aroma was so much like boiled vegetables that I couldn’t focus on the rest. Flavor is mild, light roasted malt and caramel. Medium mouthfeel and low on bitterness in finish. (051104)
50 cl bottle. Dark brown colour. Very mild aroma of roasted notes. Very smooth and pleasant flavour with notes of roastedness and some hoppy flavour too.

The best dark beer I have ever had.  Note that I have only tried the Velkopopovcky Kozel Cerny brewed in the Czech Republic.  This is the best dark beer in the world.  Not too sweet no bite, just right.

Of course, Velkopopovycky just won the gold medal in Belgium for best beer in all three categories: light, medium and dark.  This should come as no surprise to people that actually know beer.

I would also like to point out that in the Czech Republic, where Kozel comes from, 57% of the people prefer Cerny (dark) Kozel to medium, light or premium light.  I agree with them.  After all, Czechs drink more beer per capita than any other people in the world.
Dark dark brown colour. Aroma from plums and raw sugar. The palate is to thin and watery in my taste. The tast has some mild coffee and burnt malt. I´ve had better Czechs.
Dark brown colour with a small very fast disapearing head. Smooth taste of caramel and toffee. Watery and a bit too sweet for my taste, but you cant get everything for a 3,8%

Dark brown color beer with very smooth taste.  Very smooth almost ground coffee aroma.  Thin head.  Very sweet and easy on teh palate.  Easy finish. The best Czech beer there is.  Just lovely.  Must try for all.
Dark reddish brown coloured beer with a medium disappearing head. Light toffee aroma. The taste is sweet with a rather creamy palate. Very short neutral finish.

Bottled.  Nice, dark brown, with a creamy head, reasonable persistence.  Raw sugar flavour and extremely sweet, perhaps too much so.  Some chocolate and fruit flavours as well.  It’s a lot like my housemate: nice, but a bit uncoordinated.

On tap in Olomouc:



The Lure:
Creamy fruit salad sailing on an underlying bock-like malt sweetness. Roasted caramel and ashes complete the semi-complexity.



The Festivities:
Cloying caramel in an almost nitroed, soft and round body. Sweet chocolate melting into a weak roastiness. 



Transcendence:
Thick icing on a thin cake is not necessarily as enjoyable as it could be.
Bottled(500ml). -unfortunately just nice but not too good dunkel, coffee, raw sugar and caramel flavor with light hoppy notes, fruity sweet finish
Fantastic! Pours a rich red copper with a medium tan head with good lace. Aromas of toffee, sweet spice, dates. Toasted malt palate with cooked fruit in the finish (apples and raisins).

Bottle. An amazing beer for its low ABV. Dark with a dark brown hue with tan head with good retention. Sweet spicy aroma leading to a delicious palate with lots of sweet malt, some chocolate and subdued bitterness. Becomes a little bit cloying as you finish your third pint... but then again I can live with that. Good mouth feel with standard lager carbonation. You should try it on tap, where it *really* excels

On tap, Prague.  Pours deep, cola red-brown with thick tan head.   Sweet aroma of caramel and sugar.  Sweet flavors of coffee and caramel, balanced with a bit of hops.  Good mouthfeel, too: I wish the flavors lasted longer.

[on tap somewhere in the Czech Republic]
Clear, ruby-brown with good lacing and a creamy cover.  Plenty of diacetyl butterscotch in the aroma with some caramel and a hint of noble hops.  The flavour is of sweet caramel plus diacetyl with strawberry/kiwi notes.  Quite sweet with no bitterness.  Maybe  a little raisiny and brown ale-like.  Medium body and very low carbonation with a clean finish.

(Draught at U Karla, Prague.)
Dark mahogany brown. Thin white diminishing head. Sweet malty nose with hints of ham. Caramelly, roasted, malty flavour. Chewy, sweet, thick palate. Notes of liquorice.

On tap at the Pilsner Urquell restaurant, Stare Mesto, Prague.  Pretty delicious but standard taste for the dunkel variety.  Went well with the beef goulash with bread and potato-and-bacon pancakes I had with it.  Nice place.

Tasted this one from the 50cL bottle around it’s use-by date, and poured it into a tall tulip. A short, dense off-white head formed, quite slowly, atop a clear deep cola brown body. Initial peppery and Worcestershire sauce aroma subsided to reveal hints of milk chocolate, malt and dark berries. In the mouth, flavours reminiscent of a good teramisú crossed the palate, quite dessert-style malty and sweet. Fairly smooth, light in carbonation and reasonably big in flavour. Short in the swallow, with only a hint of sweetness and a feint astringent finish.  Even though it’s a little sweet it seemed to be reasonably balanced and avoids becoming too cloying. Quite sessionable and for 3.8%, you could easily sit on it all night. Quite nice!!!

(Bottle 50 cl) Dark with the typical reddish hue, but - again - this has been added artificial colouring. Light in body but the sweetish caramel-like maltines combined with soft hops makes this a pleasant beer to drink. I’ve had this in versions named "Tmavý" or "Cerný", but it’s all the same "tmavé výcepni pivo.

Bottle. Hardly any aroma, though a tiny bit of sweetness sensed. Nice dark red appearance. Sweet flavor, unfortunately with very short finish. Great mouthfeel as a thirst quencher. Overall a bit disappointing
Quite a nice dunkel. But overall impression; nothing special. It lacks body, but has a nice head.
Bottled. Licorice aroma with some sweetness. Slightly malty, sweet taste with notes of licorice and caramel. A bit thinbodied. Still, a nice Dunkel.

Nice bottle from a supermarket in Prague: the foil is gold, but burnished black at the tip. Nice Dunkel brown, with a bubbly head and a slightly rooty aroma. Medium beer. Nice, but thin choc flavour, finishing with a soured tip, even suggesting extra alcohol. This is very sweet, but pretty smooth, with some taste.

Bottle, at home.
Dark red with nica off-white head, long lasting. Nice lacings. Aroma of sweet malt and light hoppy. Flavor sweet (caramel) and light bitter. Light body, watery, lively carbonated.
Impression: To watery.
Excellent! Nice red-brown color, full head.  Light drinking for a dark, not too sweet either.  Could be stronger though.  Had from bottle in Czech Rep.

Red colour with a huge off-white head.
Malty aroma with notes of caramel and hops.
The flavour is dominated by malt with  some sweetnes and metallic notes..
Slightly bitter finish.
A bit watery, but still nice.

A clear, dark, reddish amber with a tan head. The aroma is overwhelmingly that of caramel toffee; the flavour sweet caramelized malt. I used to rate this as one of my favourites but my palate now tells me it suffers from a lack of complexity – the sweet malty flavour is the same from the nose, all around the mouth and into the aftertaste with nothing else coming through to excite greater interest.
Bottled. Dark red colour with beige small head. Fresh sweetish malt aroma. Flavor is toasted malt with a bit bitterness, but still very refreshing. Very wellbalanced.

Appetising Czech dunkel. Poured a chestnut colour with a decent frothing head. Light aroma has hitns of licorice and spices. Light-to-medium bodied with a mild flavour profile with hints of milky coffee, toffee, dried fruit and dark malt. Gentle. Some balancing bitterness. (Bottle)

Bouteille de 500 ml obtenue par un ami qui était en voyage dans le pays. Arôme: Odeur de douceur et de caramel. Apparence: Couleur brune avec des reflets de rouge. Aucun col. Légère dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Gout de caramel avec une légère pointe chocolatée. Arrière goût de durée moyenne. Palette: Corps et texture mince. Carbonisation moyenne. Légère amertume en arrière goût. (Rating #82)
Colour is slightly lighter than a lager.  Taste is a bit sweet/sour with a weak body and carbonation to support it,  dissapointing for a czech beer.
Herlig mørk øl med flot aroma og flot vedvarende skum. Har et strejf af karamel, men er trodsalt lidt vandig
Nice dark colour, with a white head that disappears a bit to early. A bit to light, a stronger beer would perhaps make a better overall finish.
Dark copper, long lasting white head, laces nicely. Caramel and metallic smell. Palate without any edges or graininess to it maybe a touch thin for my taste. Flavour fairly simple roasted malts.

Bottle. Clear brown colour with off-white head. Interesting sweet malty aroma. Dryish. A bit sour. Nutty. Notes of caramel as it warms. Sweet malty flavour. The sweetness resembles a bit the one found in the Danish ‘julehvidtøl’ beers, although not being as profound.
Bottle. Dark brown with nice head. Sweet, toffee, balancing bittermess in the finish.
A thoroughly dark beer. One of the best from Kozel. Has a wonderful nutty flavor with burnt overtones. Best just below room temperature. The top of the easily available (non-boutique) Czech beers.
Bottle.  Suprisingly light malt aroma for a dark beer.  Coffee brown color.  Light sweet coffee malt flavor with not the strongest of palates.  A very enjoyable dunkel.
Chestnut color with a nice beige head. The taste is sweet caramel malty. Rather complex malt pattern. Maybe a little thin on the palate.
Dark copper with a nice head. Light malty, slighty fruity aroma. Light malt body with taste of plums and chocolate. Short finish. Not much for hops. Refreshing.
faint taste of nuggets of toffee. again afaint scent of an old mason jar full of fermented alchohol.

dark amberish red pour, with a light tan head, poor retention.  sweet roasty carmel aroma.  light body with a nice roasty malt and slight caramel flavor, quite light for a fairly dark beer. veery drinkable.
Moderately malty, lightly hoppy aroma. Frothy, light brown head, mostly diminishing. Virtually no lace.  Brown to black body. Lightly bitter initial flavour, no finish.  Lightly bodied.
Dark brown color, Light roasted aroma, medium sweet taste, Medium body......
A very pleasant dunkel, but a bit watery. Nicely balanced and extremely drinkable.

Deep reddy brown colour with an almost light tan coloured head. The head was short lasting with no lacing. Aroma was not strong, cocoa and malt. Sweet mouthfeel was not offensive, but probably couldn’t have more than a couple, thin and smooth chocolate/cocoa texture, a little watery but easy to drink.

This is one I would certainly purchase again, providing I can find somewhere that sells it - it’s a beer that is probably difficult to find places that sell it in Melbourne. It is almost (but not quite) Guinnesslike - hence its high rating with me.
Burnt malt aroma with clear dark brown colour and no head. Burnt malt bitter flavourn with fizzy palate.
Darl golden, nice head. Has a sweet and fruity aroma from peaches. Creamy flavor, but a little watery and thin.
Amber with an offwhite head. Aroma is malty and slightly floral. Flavor is really malty and brings some cream.
Bottle. Aroma malty sweet. Appearance dark brown with large-bubbled white head. Malty and semi-sweet flavour. Not un-bitter.
Terific fruity aroma.  Tones of mollasses but a bit too much like lolly water to me.  Drink as a novelty but thats about it.

Deep red beer with a roasty, caramel and burnt toast nose.  Full roast malt flavour with some sweetness, although the taste gets dryer in the roasted, bitter aftertaste.  Good stuff.  (Bottle from Shop, Praha)
Chcolote malty aroma... Followed by a very sweet chocolate coffee taste... Nice round and mild sweet aftertaste...

Draught
